Plus, its especially economical with a price tag of about $240 for a queen size. (You can also purchase the mattress with a platform bed frame.)How We Chose Our Best Mattresses on AmazonWe chose what we’ve deemed the best mattresses on Amazon by rallying our mattress reviewers to test each mattress on our list (and many more) the same way you would when buying a mattress in a brick-and-mortar store. This included lying on the mattresses for subjective commentary on the feel, firmness, comfort for various sleeping positions, and support for those with different body types. We also employed several mattress tests that measure (and collect objective data) for factors that shoppers look for in person, such as:a cooling test that uses a thermal gun to detect temperaturea motion transfer test that uses a seismograph to measure movement across the mattress surfacea pressure relief test using a pressure map under our testersa responsiveness test that enables our testers to gauge perceived ease of movement on the mattress surfacean edge support test that measures how much a mattress sinks beneath various weights along its perimeterHaving multiple mattresses of different types from various brands in the same room helped us pinpoint their key differences, such as design, build, and overall feel. We were able to determine how much swaddling in memory foam is too much and what level of firmness went beyond actually feeling comfortable for sleep. Bouncing our feedback off of one another also helped us conclude if the mattresses were indeed sleeping much too hot or if we were just being extra picky.We also considered Amazon return policies, trial periods, and warranties to determine if buying a mattress online would be just as convenient as purchasing one in person.For more information on how we test mattresses, check out our sleep testing methodology.What to Look for When Shopping on Amazon for a MattressSure, it might be easy to go with the highest-rated or most popular mattress on Amazon, but consider a few additional factors to determine which mattress is right for you (spoiler alert: it may not be the crowd-favorite). Sleep is highly personal, and what might feel like the dream mattress to one buyer could end in a night (or many nights) of tossing and turning for you.Luckily, there are a few details you can think about to help you find the right mattress on Amazon. Here’s how to find that perfect fit—and your best night’s sleep.MaterialsMattresses are made with a wide range of materials. Depending on the mattress, you may find memory foam, cooling gel, cotton, latex, silk, bamboo, or a combination of materials.Each material serves a unique purpose. For instance, cooling gel and bamboo offer breathability and temperature regulation to keep you from sweating at night. Meanwhile, memory foam helps a mattress contour to the shape of your body to provide support and targeted pressure relief. People with allergies or sensitivities to certain materials also gravitate toward latex, which is naturally hypoallergenic.No one material is better than the other, but many buyers tend to seek out mattresses with cooling or contouring materials. Consider your goals for a new mattress (for example, do you sleep hot?) to determine which materials will help bring you some quality shut-eye.FirmnessMost mattresses come with one of three levels of firmness, such as soft, medium, or firm, or a combination like medium-soft or medium-firm. Depending on the brand, these firmness levels may have different names (such as “plush” for soft), but all generally serve the same purpose.The firmness of a mattress is essentially the support it provides, so think of soft mattresses as the least supportive and firm mattresses as the most supportive. Back sleepers tend to gravitate toward the firmer side for more lumbar support while side sleepers may like something softer.Sleep PositionLike firmness, sleep position is a personal preference that ultimately determines what type of mattress feels most comfortable to you. If you’re a side sleeper, seek out a mattress with good hip support. Meanwhile, back sleepers may like the targeted lumbar support offered by memory foam (or a hybrid mattress, which blends innerspring with memory foam).If you prefer to sleep on your stomach, consider steering away from a mattress that’s too plush, which may cause your stomach and hips to sink into the bed, causing discomfort or soreness.CoolingCooling is a key feature many mattress shoppers seek. We’ve all been there—tossing and turning all night because it’s just too hot to sleep. Cooling features help prevent body heat from getting trapped in the mattress while also increasing ventilation. Some of the materials we mentioned above, such as cooling gel, cotton, and bamboo, are naturally breathable. Some mattresses are also infused with copper, which helps disperse heat.Edge SupportEdge support is an often-overlooked mattress feature, but it can have a significant impact on your sleep quality—especially if you’re sharing your bed. To find a mattress with strong edge support, look for features like reinforced coils along the sides of a mattress. Also keep in mind that the top layers of softer beds tend to sink deeper along the edges than medium or firm beds. If you share a smaller-than-ideal bed or hug the edges of your bed while sleeping, opt for a mattress that’s as firm as your comfort allows.Trial Period and WarrantyA mattress is often a lofty investment, so it’s important to seek out a mattress with a generous trial period and warranty. After all, it can take several weeks—or even months—to fully break in a mattress, so there’s a good chance your mattress won’t feel the way it’s designed to right out of the box (or delivery truck). Trial periods vary from brand to brand but can range from 30 days to a full year.A good warranty—ideally a lifetime warranty—also helps insure your purchase in the event that something goes wrong with your mattress. Maybe the coil system fails after a year or the memory foam starts to deteriorate. Whatever the issue may be, a warranty can help cover manufacturing defects and potentially even net you a new mattress if your initial pick doesn’t meet your expectations.Amazon Mattress FAQsWhat is the best brand mattress on Amazon?There are multiple great mattress brands on Amazon that we love, including Nectar, Zinus, and Casper. However, deciding which mattress on Amazon is ultimately best for you depends on your personal preferences, including how firm you like your mattress, if you sleep hot or cool, and your sleeping style. We aimed to add all of these criteria to the mattresses we selected to make the shopping experience a little easier.What is the top-rated mattress on Amazon?The top-rated mattress on Amazon on our list is the Linenspa Innerspring, which has a 4.4/5 rating based on 138,000+ reviews. The reason this mattress is so well-loved? Buyers rave about its feel, noting that it still offers some softness for being a firm mattress. They also highlight the overall quality and value of the mattress, as well as how easy it is to set up.Should I buy a mattress on Amazon?Buying a mattress on Amazon takes the stress out of shopping in person, which may include a long trip to your local furniture store and/or potentially pushy salespeople trying to upsell you on a more expensive mattress. By shopping for a mattress on Amazon, you can easily browse verified customer reviews and have all of the product information in front of you before making a purchase.How much should I spend on an Amazon mattress?There’s really no limit as to how much you should spend on an Amazon mattress because the options range from super affordable to quite luxe. Consider setting a budget and creating a list of features that are most important to you, such as cooling or motion isolation. From there, you can shop around for a mattress that meets your needs without breaking the bank, or you can choose to sacrifice a few features for a lower price.Are mattresses returnable on Amazon?Mattress return policies vary from seller to seller, but for the most part, you can return a mattress you purchase on Amazon. To make this process easier for you, we noted above where brand and Amazon return periods for each mattress differ. In the event that a seller isn’t willing to work with you on a return, Amazon customer service is notoriously good about stepping in and helping customers out.Is it safe to buy a mattress on Amazon?Buying a mattress on Amazon can be a safe and easy way to purchase a mattress online. Our best advice: Pay close attention to the brand selling and shipping the mattress to make sure you're working with the manufacturer itself or Amazon directly rather than third-party retailers. It's also worth spending a little time in the reviews section to learn what other shoppers liked (and didn't like) about the mattress, the shipping process, and any necessary returns or refunds. Lastly, remember to compare Amazon's price with what's listed directly on the mattress brand's website to make sure you get the best deal.When is the best time to buy a mattress on Amazon?Amazon is known for hosting multiple deals events throughout the year, which can provide significant savings on an investment like a mattress. Prime Day, which occurs in July, is one of Amazon's largest sales events of the year. Amazon also runs major sales on Black Friday (and Cyber Weekend) and on holidays like Memorial Day, the Fourth of July, and Labor Day.When is it time to get a new mattress?If your mattress shows signs of fraying or sags or no longer feels comfortable, or if you often wake up achy after sleeping, it may be time to get a new mattress. On average, a mattress lasts about 10 years. If you’re nearing this window, it might also be time to replace your mattress.

How We Chose Our Best Mattresses on Amazon

We chose what we’ve deemed the best mattresses on Amazon by rallying our mattress reviewers to test each mattress on our list (and many more) the same way you would when buying a mattress in a brick-and-mortar store. This included lying on the mattresses for subjective commentary on the feel, firmness, comfort for various sleeping positions, and support for those with different body types. We also employed several mattress tests that measure (and collect objective data) for factors that shoppers look for in person, such as:

  • a cooling test that uses a thermal gun to detect temperature
  • a motion transfer test that uses a seismograph to measure movement across the mattress surface
  • a pressure relief test using a pressure map under our testers
  • a responsiveness test that enables our testers to gauge perceived ease of movement on the mattress surface
  • an edge support test that measures how much a mattress sinks beneath various weights along its perimeter

Having multiple mattresses of different types from various brands in the same room helped us pinpoint their key differences, such as design, build, and overall feel. We were able to determine how much swaddling in memory foam is too much and what level of firmness went beyond actually feeling comfortable for sleep. Bouncing our feedback off of one another also helped us conclude if the mattresses were indeed sleeping much too hot or if we were just being extra picky.

We also considered Amazon return policies, trial periods, and warranties to determine if buying a mattress online would be just as convenient as purchasing one in person.

What to Look for When Shopping on Amazon for a Mattress

Sure, it might be easy to go with the highest-rated or most popular mattress on Amazon, but consider a few additional factors to determine which mattress is right for you (spoiler alert: it may not be the crowd-favorite). Sleep is highly personal, and what might feel like the dream mattress to one buyer could end in a night (or many nights) of tossing and turning for you.

Luckily, there are a few details you can think about to help you find the right mattress on Amazon. Here’s how to find that perfect fit—and your best night’s sleep.

Materials

Mattresses are made with a wide range of materials. Depending on the mattress, you may find memory foam, cooling gel, cotton, latex, silk, bamboo, or a combination of materials.

Each material serves a unique purpose. For instance, cooling gel and bamboo offer breathability and temperature regulation to keep you from sweating at night. Meanwhile, memory foam helps a mattress contour to the shape of your body to provide support and targeted pressure relief. People with allergies or sensitivities to certain materials also gravitate toward latex, which is naturally hypoallergenic.

No one material is better than the other, but many buyers tend to seek out mattresses with cooling or contouring materials. Consider your goals for a new mattress (for example, do you sleep hot?) to determine which materials will help bring you some quality shut-eye.

Firmness

Most mattresses come with one of three levels of firmness, such as soft, medium, or firm, or a combination like medium-soft or medium-firm. Depending on the brand, these firmness levels may have different names (such as “plush” for soft), but all generally serve the same purpose.

The firmness of a mattress is essentially the support it provides, so think of soft mattresses as the least supportive and firm mattresses as the most supportive. Back sleepers tend to gravitate toward the firmer side for more lumbar support while side sleepers may like something softer.

Sleep Position

Like firmness, sleep position is a personal preference that ultimately determines what type of mattress feels most comfortable to you. If you’re a side sleeper, seek out a mattress with good hip support. Meanwhile, back sleepers may like the targeted lumbar support offered by memory foam (or a hybrid mattress, which blends innerspring with memory foam).

If you prefer to sleep on your stomach, consider steering away from a mattress that’s too plush, which may cause your stomach and hips to sink into the bed, causing discomfort or soreness.

Cooling

Cooling is a key feature many mattress shoppers seek. We’ve all been there—tossing and turning all night because it’s just too hot to sleep. Cooling features help prevent body heat from getting trapped in the mattress while also increasing ventilation. Some of the materials we mentioned above, such as cooling gel, cotton, and bamboo, are naturally breathable. Some mattresses are also infused with copper, which helps disperse heat.

Edge Support

Edge support is an often-overlooked mattress feature, but it can have a significant impact on your sleep quality—especially if you’re sharing your bed. To find a mattress with strong edge support, look for features like reinforced coils along the sides of a mattress. Also keep in mind that the top layers of softer beds tend to sink deeper along the edges than medium or firm beds. If you share a smaller-than-ideal bed or hug the edges of your bed while sleeping, opt for a mattress that’s as firm as your comfort allows.

Trial Period and Warranty

A mattress is often a lofty investment, so it’s important to seek out a mattress with a generous trial period and warranty. After all, it can take several weeks—or even months—to fully break in a mattress, so there’s a good chance your mattress won’t feel the way it’s designed to right out of the box (or delivery truck). Trial periods vary from brand to brand but can range from 30 days to a full year.

A good warranty—ideally a lifetime warranty—also helps insure your purchase in the event that something goes wrong with your mattress. Maybe the coil system fails after a year or the memory foam starts to deteriorate. Whatever the issue may be, a warranty can help cover manufacturing defects and potentially even net you a new mattress if your initial pick doesn’t meet your expectations.

Is it safe to buy a mattress on Amazon?

When is the best time to buy a mattress on Amazon?

Amazon is known for hosting multiple deals events throughout the year, which can provide significant savings on an investment like a mattress. Prime Day, which occurs in July, is one of Amazon's largest sales events of the year. When is it time to get a new mattress?

If your mattress shows signs of fraying or sags or no longer feels comfortable, or if you often wake up achy after sleeping, it may be time to get a new mattress. On average, a mattress lasts about 10 years. If you’re nearing this window, it might also be time to replace your mattress.
